titleStmt.title: An entry from the Journals of Hensley Henson

sourceDesc.bibl: Edited from the manuscripts in the custody of Durham Cathedral Library.

p.hi: Lionel went with me to Darlington, where I took train for London. On arriving at King's Cross, I
, and, leaving my bags there, proceeded to the hair–dresser, & was duly handled by him.

Then I had tea in the Athenaeum, where I fell in with the Archbishop of Canterbury, who seemed unusually vigourous and alert. He seemed resolute to carry the Revised Book again to Parliament. He says that the Bishop of Southwell asks leave to resign his bishoprick. His illness seems rather religious than physical, but very hopeless anyway. Then I walked to Westminster, & made vain attempts to see
. As I was crossing through S. Margaret's Churchyard I encountered
. He was trembling all over, & to my thinking looked woefully ill.
He thinks that the House of Commons will not reject the Prayer Book a second time.
I returned to the Athenaeum, and, after writing a few letters, dined there, having as my table–companion that old club–caterpillar,
I walked back to Park Lane, and had a short conversation with
The weather has become quite mild, and, if the rain would hold off, would be pleasant enough.
